Dear Ms. Stenzel:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on November
20, 2018. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract
and Implementation Sustainability and Exit Plan(ISEP) requirements, a written
corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules
are also violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15
days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except

4

MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of conditions,
books, records, and reports; access by department, bureau
of fire services, or local authorities; records; report; forms;
confidentiality; disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be provided
to department; failure of licensee to cooperate with
investigation, inspection, or examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department prescribes
regarding each child in its control and care and shall report to

and subsection (4), records regarding children and facts
compiled about children and their parents and relatives are
confidential and disclosure of this information shall be properly
safeguarded by the child care organization, the department, and
any other entity in possession of the information.

CI 16-182a Communication Issuance.
Security Awareness Training for Fingerprint Base Criminal
History Requirements.
Security Awareness Training (SAT) is required for authorized
personnel who have been granted access to fingerprint-based
Criminal History Record Information (CHRI). This training
provides information on what fingerprint based CHRI is, who
has access, how to ensure this information remains secure both
physically an electronically, and how you can use this
information appropriately.
Security Awareness Training is required to be completed no
later than Tuesday February 10, 2017 for all non-contracted and
governmental CPA employees, subcontractors, subcontractor’s
employees or volunteers who are authorized to have access to
fingerprint-based CHRI.
All non-contracted and governmental CPA employees,
subcontractors, subcontractor’s employees or volunteers who
are authorized to have access to fingerprint-based CHRI must
successfully complete SAT within six months of appointment to
a position with CHRI access and every two years thereafter.
Two of nine current employees listed as having access to CHRI
did not show documentation the employee completed the
required training by the 2/10/17 due date.
One of two employees hired in 2016, who left the agency in
October 2018 did not show compliance by the required 2/10/17
due date.

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12606(a)-(f) Training requirements.
The agency’s documentation of training for its domestic adoption applicants/parents
was not clearly spelled out. The agency is advised utilization of some type of receipt
acknowledgement tool and or training sheet, which documents that the
applicant/adoptive parent completed the identified trainings, may aid it in showing
clear and consistent compliance to the rule.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There were no incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s November 2017 Renewal
inspection. At that time, the agency received several rules, ISEP and policy
violations. The agency made progress with its correction plan for that inspection.
There was a decrease in the number of licensing rule violations and DHHS adoption
violations. There was an increase in the number of citations related to domestic
adoptions.
The agency experienced a few worker changes since the last inspection and it has
taken on more Interns. The agency and staff appear to have adjusted to the changes
and reports no concerns of difficulties related to them.
The second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation 2018C0420048.
The investigation related to an allegation that a licensing worker falsified information
in a reevaluation report. The agency received a citation for R400.12206(1) for Staff
qualifications and R400.12324(2)(b) for reevaluation. The agency submitted an
acceptable corrective action plan that indicated the employee involved in the incident
was terminated; and an in-service training was being provided to all staff related to
reevaluation and documentation. Additionally, that the licensing supervisor would
provide additionally oversight by conducting random quarterly reviews by contacting
workers identified in the reevaluation, to ensure authenticity.
There have been no repeat violations of the rules identified in the stated special
investigation. The agency remains in compliance with this corrective action plan.

Safety Alert #1:

Concern:
No medical passport.
Resolution
The agency reported the foster parent was provided a medical passport. Case
documentation showed the foster parent signed two separated medical passports.
Safety and Concern Alert #2:
Concern:
The bio children in the home who are opposite gender are currently sharing a bedroom.
The children are 10 & 8.
Resolution
The agency informed the foster parents of the noncompliance and immediate steps
were taken to correct the situation. The second bed in the male child’s room was taken
out; he’s now the only child in that room, which has a twin bed. The two female children
now share a bedroom, which consists of a crib and a twin bed. Photos are on file
showing the setup of both rooms.

participated in an FTM on 11/1/18.
Safety Alert #5: No concerns.
